H0.text: Trees are organisms made of one cell.

H1.text: Bacteria are organisms that consist of a single cell.

H2.text: Fern is the type of organism that is made of one cell.

H3.text: Fish are organisms made of one cell.

A4.text: Most bacterial species exist as single cells; others associate in characteristic patterns.

A5.text: Bacteria can also group to form larger multicellular structures, such as the elongated filaments of Actinomycetota species, the aggregates of Myxobacteria species, and the complex hyphae of Streptomyces species.

A6.text: Bacteria grow to a fixed size and then reproduce through binary fission, a form of asexual reproduction.

A7.text: myxobacteria aggregate to form fruiting bodies up to 500 micrometres long and containing approximately 100,000 bacterial cells.

A8.text: Some unicellular prokaryotes, such as cyanobacteria, form colonies held together by biofilms, and large colonies can create multilayered microbial mats.

A9.text: Like archaea, bacteria are prokaryotic â€“ unicellular, and having no cell nucleus or other membrane-bound organelle.

A10.text: In the Charales, which are the algae most closely related to higher plants, cells differentiate into several distinct tissues within the organism.

A11.text: Bacteria function and reproduce as individual cells, but they can often aggregate in multicellular colonies.

A12.text: Most multicellular eukaryotes consist of a single cell called a zygote only at the beginning of their life cycles.
